subject: Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"
msgSnippet: This discussion has been exactly what I have been looking for a while. Continuing this further, I woud like to bring the question of development overheads
messageBody:
This discussion has been exactly what I have been looking for a while. Continuing this further, I woud like to bring the question of development overheads involved.
1) What efforts have you guys taken in your respective organizations to reduce the programming overhead associated with writing unit tests?
2) What are the tools you use for creation of unit tests, if any?
3) Do you prefer using tools for unit tests creation?
4) We use JBuilder in our development efforst. What would you advise us to go for to reduce our development overheads associated with unit tests?
5) What do you guys think of cactus?
Thanks again for the valuable insight you guys have provided with this discussion.
Mike Clark <mike@...> wrote:J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

If you're asking me...

>I believe that building the tests needs to be performed by a human,
>because that's where the knowledge lies.
>

Yeah, I guess I'm saying it works best for me if I get to pick which
tests go into which suites. It's an organizational exercise that lends
itself to the way I run tests.

I know of many ways to search for and run all tests in the system. When
I've needed to do that, and for some reason I don't have an AllTests
suite already built, I use the Ant batchtest. I can't say I've pulled
that lever as a safeguard against forgetting to add tests to a suite
though. Alas, it's not because I have a good memory. Rather, when
building things test-first I generally notice those errors of omission
early.

>If there were a nice graphical
>tool to make it easy, would that help?
>

Perhaps. Eclipse has a wizard for creating a test suite, allowing you
to pick which test classes to include from a list of tests it
automagically finds. I haven't used it much, but think I might try it
for a while. I can always fall back to writing the suites by hand.

>Is it worth your while to build it?
>
>
I couldn't justify building it given my current needs. That's not to
say if it were built I wouldn't use it, but it's not a tool I reach for.

MIke
